title-group.article-title: Study of the volatile compounds and odor-active compounds of dry-cured Iberian ham extracted by SPME

article-meta.aff: 1Food Technology. Facultad de Veterinaria, UEx, Campus Universitario s/n, Cáceres, Spain
2Food Technology. Escuela de Ingenierías Agrarias, UEx, Carretera de Cáceres s/n, Badajoz, Spain

author-notes.corresp: José Sánchez del Pulgar, Food Technology, Facultad de Veterinaria, UEx, Campus Universitario s/n, 10003 Cáceres, Spain Email: josapuri@unex.es

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The volatile compounds and the most odor-active compounds of dry-cured Iberian ham were investigated by extracting them using a solid phase microextraction technique with a 2 cm Carboxen/PDMS/DVB fiber. The detection frequency method was applied to estimate the potential contribution of each compound to the odor of hams. Twenty-one volatile compounds were tentatively identified for the first time in dry-cured ham by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, and eight in dry-cured Iberian ham. Gas chromatography-olfactometry allowed the identification for the first time of six compounds not previously reported as odorants of Iberian ham, and also two odorants were newly identified in dry-cured ham. According to the detection frequency method, the most odor active compounds found were 3-methylbutanoic acid (dirty sock-like smelling), hexanal (cut grass-like odor), 3-methylbutanal (sweaty and bitter almond-like odor), 2-methyl-3-furanthiol (toasted nuts-like odor) and 1-octen-3-one (mushroom-like odor).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The characteristic aroma of meat products significantly contributes to their overall acceptance (Shahidi, 1994). This is particularly important in the case of Iberian ham, an expensive Spanish dry-cured ham produced from Iberian pigs, characterized by a long ripening process (420–720 days for the whole process) (Ruiz et al., 1998a) and an excellent consumer acceptance. To date, a considerable amount of studies has been conducted on dry-cured Iberian ham’s volatile compounds (reviewed by Ruiz et al., 2002), a large number of volatile compounds being identified. Nevertheless, most research focused on the study of the most abundant compounds, but only some work has been performed to investigate their potential contribution to dry-cured ham aroma. However, it is well accepted that only a limited number of volatile compounds contributes to the overall food aroma (Schieberle, 1999), and the concentration of some very potent odorants is too low to be detected by the usual gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) procedures (Carrapiso et al., 2002a).

Gas chromatography-olfactometry (GC-O) is a useful tool to identify and characterize the odor-active compounds (Mayol and Acree, 2001). The odor-active volatile compounds of dry-cured hams have already been studied by using different extraction techniques (Blank et al., 2001; Carrapiso et al., 2002a, b, 2010; Carrapiso and García, 2004, 2007; Flores et al., 1997; Song et al., 2008; Song and Cadwallader, 2008; Thèron et al., 2010). For Iberian ham, most studies used a purge and trap extraction technique, which tend to extract poorly polar or heavy compounds such as acids (Mallia et al., 2005), so there is little information about the contribution of those odor-active compounds to the overall odor of Iberian dry-cured ham.

Solid-phase microextraction (SPME) rapidly has emerged as a robust technique for the rapid, solventless extraction or pre-concentration of volatile and semi-volatile organic compounds in a variety of scientific disciplines (reviewed by Harmon, 2002). It utilizes a partitioning of organic components between a bulk aqueous or vapor phase and the thin polymeric films coated onto fused silica fibers in the SPME apparatus (reviewed by Harmon, 2002). SPME offers some advantages over other extraction methods: being a solventless method, it is not necessary to heat the extract to evaporate solvents (reviewed by Harmon, 2002), and it is more efficient extracting the heavy compounds usually found in foods (aldehydes, alcohols, esters and ketones with more than six carbon atoms) and acids than other solventless methods like purge and trap (Mallia et al., 2005). Therefore, the SPME technique would be useful for a better understanding of Iberian ham aroma. In previous studies about dry-cured ham, for example, acids were identified only as odorants of spoiled Iberian hams (Carrapiso et al., 2010) but not of unspoiled ones (Carrapiso et al., 2002a,b; Carrapiso and García, 2004, 2007) when extracted by purge and capture, and Song and Cadwallader (2008) found as odorants of American country ham much more acids when extracted by direct solvent extraction-solvent assisted flavor evaporation than by purge and capture. So, the use of SPME to contribute to the characterization of the most odor-active compounds, with its better efficiency for extracting acids, and high weight aldehydes, esters and ketones, could extend the knowledge about the major odorants of dry-cured Iberian ham.

Therefore, the purpose of the present study was to identify and characterize the most odor-active compounds of dry-cured Iberian ham by SPME-GC-O and the volatile compounds by SPME-GC-MS in order to contribute to the characterization of the Iberian ham odor.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: The Iberian dry-cured hams were obtained from 35 Iberian × Duroc 75% pigs (female pure Iberian × male Iberian × Duroc 50% pigs) controlled by the Protected Denomination of Origin ‘Dehesa de Extremadura’. After slaughtering, the hams were processed for 720 days following the procedure described by García et al. (1996) and the regulations for Iberian products (R.D. 1469/2007) and Dehesa de Extremadura hams (Orden de 2 de Julio de 1990).

A piece of the Biceps femoris muscle was taken, vacuum packaged, frozen and kept at −80 °C until the analysis. The samples were analyzed for composition: moisture content was 44.98 ± 4.49% (AOAC, 1984), intramuscular fat content was 5.80 ± 1.90% (Folch, 1957), protein content was 33.67 ± 1.94% (ISO-973, 1978), and salt content was 3.29 ± 0.74% (AOAC, 1984). Ten samples (chosen randomly) underwent a SPME-GC-O analysis, and all the samples underwent a SPME-GC-MS analysis.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: The reference compounds of the volatile compounds listed in Table 1 were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Steinhein, Germany). Standard solutions were prepared at a concentration of 5 µl/mL of reference compound in dichloromethane or hexane (HPLC grade).

sec.title: Isolation of volatile compounds
sec.p: Before the analysis, the surface of each sample (0.5 cm) and the visible fat were removed. Frozen samples were then grinded, and 5 g were introduced in a 20 mL vial (21 mL actual volume), which was screw-capped with a laminated Teflon-rubber disk and left at 37 °C for 25 min to equilibrate the volatiles in the headspace. Then, a solid-phase micro extraction (SPME) needle was introduced into the vial piercing its septum, and a 2 cm Carboxen/PDMS/DVB fiber (75 µm thickness, Supelco, Bellefonte, PA) was exposed to the headspace for 30 min while the vial was in the 37 °C water bath. After the isolation of the volatile compounds, the fiber was injected and kept for 15 min in the inlet (250 °C, splitless mode) of a gas-chromatograph (GC).

sec.title: Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry
sec.p: GC-MS analysis was performed on an Agilent 6890 series GC coupled to a MS detector (Agilent 5973) and equipped with a DB-5 capillary column. The oven conditions were equal to those applied for GC-O analysis by using this column. Mass spectra were generated by electronic impact at 70 eV, with a multiplier voltage of 1675 V. Data were collected at a rate of 1 scan/s over de m/z range 30–300. The transfer line to the mass spectrometer was maintained at 280 °C. Compounds were identified by comparison of mass spectra and LRI with those of reference compounds or tentatively identified by comparison with mass spectra comprised in the Wiley and the NIST/EPA/NIH mass spectra library and LRI previously reported. (NIST: http://webbook.nist.gov; The Linear Retention Index and Odour Database: http://www.odour.org.uk).

sec.title: Gas chromatography-olfactometry
sec.p: A gas-chromatograph (GC) (Agilent 6890 series) equipped with a mass spectrum detector (MS) (Agilent 5973) and an olfactory detector (ODO II, SGE Analitycal Science, Australia) was used. The effluent from the capillary column was split 1 : 1 (v : v) between the MS and the sniffing port using two deactivated but uncoated fused silica capillaries (50 cm × 0.32 mm). DB-5 (50 m × 0.32 mm i.d, 1.05 µm) (Agilent, Avondale, USA) and DB-FFAP (60 m × 0.32 mm i.d, 1.05 µm) capillary columns were used. For the analysis with the DB-5 column, the oven temperature was held at 40 °C for 10 min and programmed to rise 5 °C/min to a temperature of 200 °C, and then to rise 20 °C/min to a final temperature of 250 °C, where it was held for 5 min (total run-time 49.5 min). For the analysis with the DB-FFAP column, the oven conditions were as follows: 50 °C for 5 min, programmed to rise 5 °C/min to a temperature of 180 °C, and then to around 10 °C min−1 to 220 °C, maintaining this temperature during 1 min. After this, the oven was programmed to rise 20 °C/min to a temperature of 250 °C, where it was held for 17.5 min (total run-time 55 min). Humidified air was added in the sniffing port at 500 mL/min.

sec.title: Odor detection frequency
sec.p: The detection frequency (DF) method (Pollien et al., 1997) was used to estimate the relative contribution of the odorants. A panel of seven assessors was selected among people experienced in sensory analysis and it was trained in GC-O using reference compounds solutions and the volatile compounds isolated by SPME from Iberian dry-cured ham samples. During the analysis, panellists were asked to describe each perceived odor, even if they did not recognize it. They were also asked about its length and intensity in order to help the identification of the odorants. Each assessor smelled the chromatographic effluent from the 10 samples that underwent SPME-CG-O analysis using the non-polar column (DB-5) (7 assessors × 10 samples).

The DF of odors having similar description and the same linear retention index (LRI) was calculated as the number of times they were smelled. Each odor peak was considered only if it was smelled in at least the 10% of the times (at least 7 times).

sec.title: Odorant identification
sec.p: The identification of the odorants was performed by matching odor descriptions, LRI of odor peaks and mass spectra obtained from the 70 replicates in the non-polar column (DB-5) and from eight additional replicates (2 samples smelled by 4 assessors) in the polar column (DB-FFAP) with those of reference compounds under the same conditions on both the polar and non-polar columns, or with odor description and LRI previously reported. (Flavornet: http://www.flavornet.org; NIST: http://webbook.nist.gov; The Linear Retention Index and Odour Database: http://www.odour.org.uk). n-Alkanes (C5–C18 for DB-5 column and C5–C25 for DB-FFAP) were analyzed under the same conditions in order to calculate the LRI values.

sec.title: Volatile compounds by SPME-GC-MS
sec.p:
The volatile compounds found in the headspace of dry-cured Iberian hams are presented in Table 2, and the odorants in Table 1. A large number of volatile compounds were identified or tentatively identified, and to the best of our knowledge, 21 of them were tentatively identified for the first time in dry-cured ham (2,3-dimethylbutane; 2,5-dimethylhexane; 2,4-dimethylhexane; 2,3,3-trimethylpentane; 4-methylheptane; 4-ethyliden-cyclohexene; 2,5-dimethyldecane; cyclodecane; 2-octanol; 2,4-pentanedione; 3-heptanone; ethyl formate; ethyl-1-methylhexanoate; anyline; N-ethyl-anyline; 1-(methylthio)-pentane; 2-methylfurane; ethoxy-ethane; 2-methylbenzoxazol; 2-(2-ethoxyethoxy)-ethane; and 1,4-dimethoxy-benzene). Furthermore, eight additional compounds were identified for the first time in dry-cured Iberian ham: 2-methylcyclopentanone; 2-ethyl-cyclopentanone; 2-pentanol; phenyl-ethanone; 5-propyl-dihydro-2-(3H)-furanone; methylpyrazine; 1-methoxy-2-propanol and 2-butoxy-ethanol. The finding of these compounds not previously reported in Iberian nor other dry-cured hams could be due to the use of a SPME fiber longer than usual (2 cm vs 1 cm), which contains more absorbent material and therefore it can extract a higher amount of volatile compounds. However, some volatile compounds identified in dry-cured Iberian ham by other authors were not found, like the unsaturated aldehydes 2-nonenal (Carrapiso et al., 2003), 2,4-nonadienal (Dirinck et al., 1997; Sabio et al., 1998) and 2,4-decadienal (Cava et al., 2000; Dirinck et al., 1997; García et al., 1991; Luna et al., 2006; Ruiz et al., 1999, 2002). They were neither identified acids with more than eight carbon atoms, as decanoic acid, dodecanoic acid (Andrés et al., 2002; Dirinck et al., 1997) and tetradecanoic acid (Dirinck et al., 1997) nor their derived esters, like ethyl-decanoate (García et al., 1991; López et al., 1992; Ruiz et al., 1999) nor propyl-decanoate (Ruiz et al., 1999). The sulphur-containing compounds hydrogen sulfide (Carrapiso et al., 2003), dimethyl trisulfide (Ruiz et al., 1998b, 1999; Sabio et al., 1998) and dimethyl tetrasulfide (Ruiz et al., 1999), the lactone γ-nonalactone (García et al., 1991; López et al., 1992) and the terpenes 3-carene (Sabio et al., 1998; Ruiz et al., 1999) and β-pinene (Ruiz et al., 1998b; Sabio et al., 1998) were neither identified. These differences could be explained in the bases of the volatile extraction methods, because the purge and trap extraction with cold Tenax trap (used in most of these studies) and the SPME technique offer a potential different profile of volatile compounds (d’Acampora Zellner et al., 2008; Harmon, 2002; Nongonierma et al., 2006; Plutowska and Wardencki, 2008; Reineccius, 2010).

sec.title: Odor-active compounds by SPME-GC-O
sec.p: The odor-active compounds of Iberian dry-cured ham were studied, and their potential role in the aroma of the Iberian ham was investigated by the odor detection frequency method. Table 1 shows the odor peaks, the identified compounds and their detection frequency (DF). A total of 21 odor peaks was found, corresponding to 20 identified compounds (2 of them in coelution) and 2 unidentified compounds. The GC-O analysis allowed the identification of seven volatile compounds that were not found by GC-MS in these hams: 2-pentenal, 2-acetyl-1-pyrroline, ethylpentanoate, 2-methyl-3-furanthiol, 1-octen-3-one, 1,5-octanodien-3-one and furaneol.

Otherwise, six of the identified compounds had not been found as major odorants in dry-cured Iberian ham previously, including 2-pentenal, ethyl-3-methylbutanoate, ethylpentanoate, 2,6-dimethylpyrazine and 1,5-octadien-3-one. Furthermore, butanoic acid, 3-methylbutanoic acid and phenylacetaldehyde (odorants of bone-tainted dry-cured Iberian ham, (Carrapiso et al., 2010) were also reported for the first time as odorants of unspoiled dry-cured Iberian ham. Two of the newly identified Iberian ham odorants (2-pentenal and ethylpentanoate) had not been found as major odorants of other dry-cured hams (Flores et al., 1997; Song and Cadwallader, 2008; Song et al., 2008; Théron et al., 2010).

Among the newly identified Iberian ham odorants, 2-pentenal is a linear unsaturated aldehyde, whose probable origin is the oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids. It has been found in dry-cured ham by GC-MS (Bolzoni et al., 1996; Dirinck et al., 1997; García-Esteban et al., 2004), and it is also one of the most odor-active compounds of cheese (Berdagué et al., 2007) and cooked pork (Xie et al., 2008). Esters come mainly from fatty acids, via esterification of acids and alcohols (Ruiz et al., 2002; Shahidi et al., 1986). Ethyl-3-methylbutanoate has been found as one of the major odorants of Bayonne ham (Théron et al., 2008) and Jinhua ham (Song et al., 2008). Ethylpentanoate has been identified as one of the most odor-active compounds of fermented sausages (Stahnke, 1994) and cheese (Frank et al., 2004). 2,6-dimethylpyrazine has a probable origin in the reactions of sulfur-containing amino acids, like methionine (Yu & Ho, 1995), cysteine (Pripis-Nicolau et al., 2000) and lysine (Meynier and Mottram, 1994). This compound has been found by GC-O in Serrano ham (Flores et al., 1997) and Bayonne ham (Théron et al., 2008). It has also been described as one of the major odorants of salami (Meynier et al., 1999), cheese (Frank et al., 2004) and chocolate (Afoakwa et al., 2009). At last, 1,5-octadien-3-one was tentatively identified by comparing the LRI in the DB-5 column and the odor description with bibliographic data. To the best of our knowledge, this compound has never been identified by GC-MS in dry-cured ham, but it has been described as one of the most odor-active compounds of Jinhua ham (Song et al., 2008) and American Country ham (Song and Cadwallader, 2008).

In this study some odor-active compounds detected previously in dry-cured Iberian ham by Carrapiso et al. (2002a,b) and by Carrapiso and García (2004, 2007), like hydrogen sulfide, methanethiol, 2-methylpropanal, 1-penten-3-one, 2-pentanone, pentanal, 2-heptenal, dimethyl trysulfide and 2-octenal were not found. It could be due to the differences in the extraction method (SPME vs purge and trap) and also in the temperature applied during the extraction, which has a marked influence on Iberian ham odorants (Carrapiso and García, 2007).

As it is shown in Table 1, the five most odor-active compounds were three aldehydes, one sulphur-containing compound and one ketone. Although 2-methyl-3-furanthiol and 1-octen-3-one were two of the five most odor-active compounds, they were not found in the CG-MS analysis (Table 2). These compounds have got an odor detection threshold of 0.005 and 0.05 ppb, respectively (Burdock, 2005), so they are more easily detectable by GC-O than by GC-MS. Other compounds not detected by using GC-MS but found via the GC-O analysis have also got a low odor detection threshold, like furaneol (0.03 ppb), ethylpentanoate (1.5 ppb) and 2-pentenal (1.5 ppb) (Burdock, 2005). Nevertheless, the compound showing the highest DF values, 3-methylbutanoic acid, has got an odor detection threshold of 190 ppb (Burdock, 2005), much higher than the compounds mentioned above. The identification of important compounds not found by CG-MS remarks the importance of the GC-O method to characterize the volatile compounds of the dry-cured ham, especially from the point of view of the comprehension of Iberian ham odor and the study of the volatile compounds having more impact in the odor perception of the dry-cured ham.

Figure 1 shows the percentage of the total detection frequencies obtained for the six odor groups in which the odorants were classified. The biggest percentage (25%) of DF was reached by the group related to dirty and sweaty odors, which included 3-methylbutanal (2), butanoic acid (7) and 3-methylbutanoic acid (9). The next biggest percentage (22%) was for the toasted odor group, with the compounds 2-acetyl-1-pyrroline (12), methional (14), 2,6-dimethylpyrazine (15), 2-methyl-3-furanthiol (16) and furaneol (21). The group of grassy odors showed the 17% of the total DF, and it was formed by the compounds 2-methylbutanal (3), methylbutanoate (4) and hexanal (8). The 15% of the DF corresponded to the group of fruity-flowery odors, formed by 2-pentenal (6), ethyl-2-methylbutanoate (10), ethyl-3-methylbutanoate (10), ethylpentanoate (13), octanal (19) and phenylacetaldehyde (20). The group of earth-fungal-like odors showed the 13% of the total DF, and was formed by 1-octen-3-one (17), 1,5-octadien-3-one (17) and the unidentified compound with wet woody and sweaty odor (5). At last, the group of dairy-milky odors showed the 8% of the total DF, and was formed by 2,3-butanedione (1) and an unidentified compound with a heated cheese odor (11). Figure 1.
Percentage of the total detection frequencies corresponding to the different odor groups. Grassy: peaks 3, 4 and 8. Earth-fungal: peaks 5, 17 and 18. Fruity-flowery: peaks 6, 10, 13, 19 and 20. Toasted: peaks 12, 14, 15, 16 and 21. Dairy-Milky: 1 and 11. Dirt-sweat: peaks 2, 7 and 9.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The extraction of volatile compounds by using a 2 cm Carboxen/PDMS/DVB fiber seems to be a good option to contribute to the characterization of Iberian ham aroma, especially to investigate the potential contribution of relatively polar or high molecular-weight compounds, such as furaneol, which are poorly extracted by static headspace or purge and trap techniques.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was financed by the Comisión Interministerial de Ciencia y Tecnología (CICYT) (AGL2005-07-07153-C02-01 project). José Sánchez del Pulgar was beneficiary of a grant from the Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovación.
